howItWorks.title: How Profit Margin Calculation Works
howItWorks.explanation: Profit margin measures how much of each dollar in revenue translates to profit. There are three key margins: Gross margin (after COGS), Operating margin (after operating expenses), and Net margin (after all expenses including taxes and interest).

steps.name: Step 3

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Include other expenses (taxes, interest, depreciation)

seoTips: Track all three margin types (gross, operating, net) for complete profitability picture
Compare margins month-over-month and year-over-year to spot trends
Benchmark against industry standards - retail averages 2-5%, software 70-80%

commonMistakes.title: Confusing Markup with Margin
commonMistakes.description: Markup is calculated on cost, while margin is calculated on revenue. A 50% markup equals only 33% margin - these are not interchangeable.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Operating Expenses
commonMistakes.description: Focusing only on gross margin while ignoring operating costs gives an incomplete picture. Net margin reveals true profitability.

commonMistakes.title: Not Accounting for All Costs
commonMistakes.description: Forgetting indirect costs like shipping, returns, payment processing fees, and overhead leads to inflated margin estimates.

commonMistakes.title: Comparing Across Different Industries
commonMistakes.description: Profit margins vary dramatically by industry. Comparing a grocery store's 2% margin to a software company's 80% margin is meaningless.

faqs.question: What is a good profit margin?
faqs.answer: Good margins vary by industry. Retail: 2-5%, Manufacturing: 5-10%, Professional Services: 15-25%, Software/SaaS: 70-85%. Compare to your specific industry benchmarks.

faqs.question: What's the difference between gross and net margin?
faqs.answer: Gross margin only deducts direct production costs (COGS), while net margin deducts all expenses including operations, taxes, and interest. Net margin shows true bottom-line profitability.

faqs.question: How can I improve my profit margin?
faqs.answer: Increase prices, reduce COGS through better supplier terms, cut operating expenses, improve operational efficiency, or shift product mix toward higher-margin items.

faqs.question: Why is my gross margin high but net margin low?
faqs.answer: This indicates high operating expenses relative to revenue. Review overhead costs, staffing efficiency, and administrative expenses for optimization opportunities.

faqs.question: Should I prioritize revenue growth or margin improvement?
faqs.answer: Both matter. Generally, improving margins on existing sales is more efficient than growing revenue with poor margins. Healthy margins enable sustainable growth.

seoTips: Standard retail markup is typically 50-100% (keystone pricing is 100% or 2x cost)
Convert markup to margin for financial reporting: Margin = Markup / (1 + Markup)
Higher markups are justified by value-added services, exclusivity, or convenience

commonMistakes.title: Confusing Markup with Margin
commonMistakes.description: A 50% markup yields only 33% margin. Markup is based on cost; margin is based on selling price. They're not interchangeable.

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting All Costs
commonMistakes.description: Only marking up product cost ignores shipping, storage, handling, and overhead. Include all costs in your base for accurate pricing.

commonMistakes.title: Using Same Markup for All Products
commonMistakes.description: Different products have different price sensitivity and competition. Vary markup based on market conditions and product category.

commonMistakes.title: Not Accounting for Discounts
commonMistakes.description: If you plan to offer discounts or promotions, build that into your base markup to maintain profitability.

faqs.question: What's the difference between markup and margin?
faqs.answer: Markup is added to cost: Selling Price = Cost + Markup. Margin is part of price: Selling Price = Cost / (1 - Margin). 100% markup = 50% margin.

faqs.question: What is keystone pricing?
faqs.answer: Keystone pricing is a 100% markup (2x cost). A $50 cost item sells for $100. It's a traditional retail benchmark, though many industries use different standards.

faqs.question: How do I calculate markup from selling price?
faqs.answer: Markup % = ((Selling Price - Cost) / Cost) × 100. If cost is $40 and price is $60: (60-40)/40 × 100 = 50% markup.

faqs.question: What markup should I use for my industry?
faqs.answer: Varies by industry: Grocery 5-15%, Clothing 100-300%, Jewelry 100-400%, Electronics 30-50%, Restaurants 300% on food. Research your specific market.

faqs.question: How do I convert markup to profit margin?
faqs.answer: Margin = Markup / (1 + Markup). For 50% markup: 0.50 / 1.50 = 33.3% margin. For 100% markup: 1.00 / 2.00 = 50% margin.

commonMistakes.title: Comparing Percentages Only
commonMistakes.description: A higher discount percentage doesn't always mean better value. Always compare final prices and absolute savings.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Original Price Inflation
commonMistakes.description: Some sellers inflate original prices before sales. Research typical prices to ensure you're getting a real discount.

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Additional Costs
commonMistakes.description: Shipping, taxes, or service fees can eliminate discount savings. Calculate total cost, not just discounted price.

commonMistakes.title: Sequential Discount Confusion
commonMistakes.description: Two 20% discounts don't equal 40% off. The second discount applies to the already-reduced price: 20% + 20% = 36% total.

faqs.question: How do I calculate the discount percentage?
faqs.answer: Discount % = ((Original Price - Sale Price) / Original Price) × 100. For example, $80 sale price on $100 original = 20% discount.

faqs.question: How do stacked discounts work?
faqs.answer: Apply discounts sequentially. A $100 item with 20% off then 10% off: $100 × 0.80 = $80, then $80 × 0.90 = $72 (28% total discount).

faqs.question: What's a good discount to look for?
faqs.answer: It depends on the product. Electronics: 15-30% is good. Clothing: 30-50% during sales. Luxury items: even 10-15% is significant.

faqs.question: Is 'Buy One Get One 50% Off' better than 25% off?
faqs.answer: They're equivalent if you buy two items at the same price. BOGO 50% off two $100 items = $150 total (25% off each item effectively).

faqs.question: How do I find the original price from a sale price?
faqs.answer: Original Price = Sale Price / (1 - Discount%/100). A $60 item at 25% off: $60 / 0.75 = $80 original price.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Waste

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Storage Costs

faqs.question: Is bigger always cheaper per unit?
faqs.answer: Not always. Sometimes medium sizes or sale items offer better unit prices. Always calculate rather than assume.

faqs.question: How do I compare different units?
faqs.answer: Convert to the same unit first. 1 kg = 35.27 oz = 2.2 lbs. Then divide price by quantity in common units.

faqs.question: Should I always buy the lowest unit price?
faqs.answer: Consider freshness, storage, and whether you'll use it all. Wasted product isn't a bargain regardless of unit price.

faqs.question: Are warehouse clubs always cheaper?
faqs.answer: Not always. Regular stores on sale may beat warehouse prices. Factor in membership cost and compare specific items.

faqs.question: What about quality differences?
faqs.answer: Unit price compares value within similar quality. A premium product may be worth paying more per unit for better quality.

interpretations.elastic: Demand is sensitive to price changes. A price increase will significantly reduce demand and may lower total revenue.
interpretations.inelastic: Demand is not very sensitive to price changes. Price increases may boost total revenue despite lower sales volume.

howItWorks.title: How Price Elasticity Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Price Elasticity = (% Change in Quantity) / (% Change in Price)
howItWorks.explanation: Price elasticity measures how sensitive demand is to price changes. Elastic demand (>1) means quantity changes more than price - a 10% price increase causes more than 10% drop in sales. Inelastic demand (<1) means quantity changes less than price changes.

seoTips: Elasticity > 1: Elastic demand - lower prices increase revenue
Elasticity < 1: Inelastic demand - higher prices increase revenue
Luxury goods tend to be elastic; necessities tend to be inelastic
Elasticity varies by price point - test at multiple levels

commonMistakes.title: Using Too Short a Time Period
commonMistakes.description: Consumers take time to adjust behavior. Short-term elasticity may differ from long-term. Allow time for demand to stabilize.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Other Factors
commonMistakes.description: Demand changes may be due to seasonality, competition, or economy, not just your price change. Control for other variables.

commonMistakes.title: Assuming Constant Elasticity
commonMistakes.description: Elasticity varies at different price points. A product may be inelastic at low prices but elastic at high prices.

commonMistakes.title: Confusing Revenue with Profit
commonMistakes.description: Elasticity predicts revenue impact. Profit depends on margins too. Lower prices may increase revenue but reduce profit.

faqs.question: What does elastic vs inelastic mean?
faqs.answer: Elastic demand (>1) is price-sensitive - quantity changes more than price. Inelastic (<1) is price-insensitive - quantity changes less. At exactly 1, changes are proportional.

faqs.question: How do I use elasticity for pricing?
faqs.answer: If demand is elastic, lower prices increase revenue. If inelastic, raise prices. Unitary elasticity means revenue stays same regardless of price.

faqs.question: What products are typically elastic?
faqs.answer: Luxuries, products with substitutes, big purchases, and non-essentials. Examples: vacations, brand-name goods, new cars.

faqs.question: What products are typically inelastic?
faqs.answer: Necessities, addictive goods, products without substitutes, and small purchases. Examples: gasoline, medicine, salt.

faqs.question: What is cross-price elasticity?
faqs.answer: Measures how demand for your product changes when a competitor or related product changes price. Positive for substitutes, negative for complements.

seoTips: Calculate total cost at tier thresholds to find true breakpoints
Include storage and carrying costs when evaluating larger purchases
Consider cash flow impact of larger upfront purchases
Combine orders with partners or colleagues to reach better tiers
Watch for expiration dates - bulk savings mean nothing if products expire

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Carrying Costs
commonMistakes.description: Bulk savings may be offset by storage, insurance, and capital tied up in inventory. Calculate true total cost.

commonMistakes.title: Buying Beyond Need
commonMistakes.description: Reaching a higher tier isn't worthwhile if you can't use the extra units. Waste eliminates savings.

commonMistakes.title: Missing Tier Breakpoints
commonMistakes.description: Ordering just below a tier threshold is worst value. Check if a few more units reaches better pricing.

commonMistakes.title: Not Comparing Total Costs
commonMistakes.description: A higher discount percentage doesn't always mean lowest total cost. Calculate actual dollars spent.

faqs.question: When should I order more to reach the next tier?
faqs.answer: When the savings at the next tier exceed the cost of extra units. Calculate: (Extra units × New price) vs (Original quantity × Old price - New price).

faqs.question: How do I compare suppliers with different tier structures?
faqs.answer: Calculate total cost at your typical order quantities for each supplier. The lowest total cost wins, not the highest discount percentage.

faqs.question: Should I always buy in bulk?
faqs.answer: Not always. Consider storage costs, spoilage/obsolescence, cash flow, and whether you'll actually use the quantity before expiration or technology changes.

faqs.question: What's a typical bulk discount structure?
faqs.answer: Common structures: 5% at 10 units, 10% at 25 units, 15% at 50 units, 20% at 100+ units. Varies widely by industry and product.

faqs.question: Can I negotiate better bulk pricing?
faqs.answer: Often yes, especially for large orders. Ask about price matching, combined shipping discounts, or contract pricing for regular orders.
